Input,:math:`\text{CO}_2` Land Use Conversion Emission Factor,Annual :math:`\text{CO}_2` emission factor for conversion of land use of type ``$CAT-LANDUSE-DIM1$`` to ``$CAT-LANDUSE-DIM2$`` due to biomass carbon stock change.,"``ef_lndu_conv_$CAT-LANDUSE-DIM1$_to_$CAT-LANDUSE-DIM2$_$UNIT-MASS$_$EMISSION-GAS$_$UNIT-AREA$`` (``$UNIT-MASS$ = gg``, ``$EMISSION-GAS$ = co2``, ``$UNIT-AREA$ = ha``)",all,,0,1,1,,0,none,,,
Input,Fraction of Increasing Net Exports Met,"
column2: Fractional of changes to net exports to meet. Values less than 1 reduce endogenous production rates (yields in crops, heads per acre in livestock) if changes to net imports are negative.
**Note**: Applied **after carrying capacity scalars** are accounted for.",``frac_lndu_increasing_net_exports_met_$CAT-LANDUSE$``,``croplands``

**Note**: Applied **after carrying capacity scalars** are accounted for.",``frac_lndu_increasing_net_imports_met_$CAT-LANDUSE$``,``croplands``

Input,Fraction of Soils Mineral,See ` Giulia Conchedda and Francesco N. Tubiello (2020) <https://doi.org/10.5194/essd-12-3113-2020>`_; 3% of soils globally are organic. Default value of 0.97 is assumed to be complement.,``frac_lndu_soil_mineral_$CAT-LANDUSE$``,all,,1,1,1,,0,none,,,

Input,Initial Fraction of Area with Drained Organic Soils,"Fraction of the land use area associated with drained organic soils--used to represent emissions from Peatland and Muck that has been drained to accommodate croplands and grassland expansion. After the initial time period, land use transitions guide drained organic soils.",``frac_lndu_initial_with_drained_organic_soils_$CAT-LANDUSE$``,``croplands``
column3: See Volume 4, Chapter 2, Equation 2.26 (ANNUAL CARBON LOSS FROM DRAINED ORGANIC SOILS).

column2: Per Volume 4, Chapter 6, Section 6.2.3.1 (pg 6-15 in 2006 IPCC GNGHGI), grasslands are not included because they are not managed--pastures represent the managed grassland state: _""Equation 2.26 (Chapter 2) is used to estimate C stock change in managed grassland on organic soils (e.g., peat- derived, Histosols). The methodology is to stratify managed organic soils by climate region and assign a climate-specific annual emission rate. Land areas are multiplied by the emission factor and then summed to derive annual C emissions. Natural grasslands that may be used for seasonal grazing but have not been artificially drained should not be included in this category.""_"

column1: Input,Land Use Yield Reallocation Factor,"The land use yield reallocation factor :math:`\eta \in [0, 1]` is used to represent land use responsiveness to changes in demands.

column2: If :math:`\eta = 1`, then **land use will be reallocated**, diverging from the specified transition matrix. If demands exceed carrying capacity to meet all livestock and crop demands, then the transitions into grassland and cropland are increased to meet demands. If the carrying capacity exceeds demand, then transitions to grassland and croplands are reduced (which also increases forested land).

If :math:`\eta = 0`, then **land use will remain as specified**, and all remaining demands with be met with net imports. If the demand is less then carrying capacity, then there is an increase in net exports; if demand exceeds carrying capacity, there is an increase in net imports.
For :math:`\eta \in (0, 1)`, there is a mix of reallocation and net imports, which scales linearly between extremes.

column1:
,``lndu_reallocation_factor``,none,,0,0,2,,0,none,,,
Input,Maximum Area,
column2: Maximum allowable area for a given category--can be used to cap feasible transitions based on geography and climate constraints.
To run without a constraint, use -999",``area_lndu_supremum_$CAT-LANDUSE$_$UNIT-AREA$`` (``$UNIT-AREA$ = ha``),all,,-999,1,1,,0,none,,,

column1: Input,Maximum Pasture Dry Matter Yield Factor,"
column2: Maximum potential yield of pastures in tonne/ha/month. The number of grazing animals that pasture can support are bounded by the maximum potential yield. The number of AU (animal units) implied by carrying capacity cannot exceed this number.

Default maximum value taken from `FarmBrite <https://www.farmbrite.com/post/how-many-cows-can-i-keep-per-acre>`_ under the assumption of technically feasible maximum--excellent pasture with irrigation, or 6,900 lb/acre. Using a conversion of 907.1858189 short tonne per kg, we use 3.45 ston/acre => 3129.791075205 kg/acre. The, using 0.404686 ha/acre, we get 7733.875338422877 kg/ha, or 7.734 tonne/ha/month as a default maximum. This is approximateluy 92.81 when expanded to annual.

**NOTE:** This number varies significantly by geography, climate, and pasture utilization rate, and users should take care to set it. In transformations, it can be increased by increasing the prevalenceo of irrigation in drier regions, though this increases water requirements for pastures significantly. ","``yf_lndu_supremum_$CAT-LANDUSE$_$UNIT-MASS$_per_$UNIT-AREA$`` (``$UNIT-AREA$ = ha``, ``$UNIT-MASS$ = tonne``)",``pastures``,,92.81,1,1,,0,none,none,,

column1: Input,Maximum Soil Carbon Land Input Factor Without Manure,"
column2: See :math:`F_{I}` in Equation 2.25 and Box 2.2, V4, C2 IPPC GNGHGI (2019R).

Used to represent supremum of soil carbon storage if residues are used as inputs (no manure)",``factor_lndu_soil_inputs_supremum_without_manure_$CAT-LANDUSE$``,``croplands``,,1,1,1,,0,none,,2019R:V4:C2:EQ2.25,

column1: Input,Maximum Soil Carbon Land Management Factor,"
column2: See :math:`F_{MG}` in Equation 2.25 and Box 2.2, V4, C2 IPPC GNGHGI (2019R) and Table 5.5.

Used to represent supremum of soil carbon storage due to management practices if no-till is used (croplands) or with sustainable management (grasslands)",``factor_lndu_soil_management_supremum_$CAT-LANDUSE$``,``croplands``
